items.abstract: <jats:title>Zusammenfassung</jats:title><jats:p>Im vorliegenden Artikel wird die Vielfalt an möglichen und derzeit im Handel angebotenen Alternativen zum klassischen Süßungsmittel Saccharose systematisiert. Ausgewählte Vertreter unterschiedlicher Gruppen werden im Speziellen hinsichtlich deren Süßkraft, Energiegehalt und glykämischem Index bewertet. Zusätzliche gesundheits- und umweltrelevante Aspekte werden beleuchtet. So werden die Biotransformation, die Persistenz in der Umwelt, die Energiebilanz, oder die ernährungsphysiologischen Auswirkungen und/oder Verträglichkeiten ausgewählter Substanzen anhand der aktuellen Wissenschaftsliteratur diskutiert und erläutert. Grundsätzlich orientiert sich der Beitrag dazu an einer Einteilung in 3 Stoffgruppen: Zucker im weiteren Sinne, Süßstoffe und Zuckeraustauschstoffe. Zuletzt wird ein mögliches neues Produktionsverfahren zur Herstellung des Zuckeraustauschstoffs Erythrit aus biogenen Reststoffen angesprochen.</jats:p>
title: Alternative Süßungsmittel

container-title: Gene Expression Systems in Fungi: Advancements and Applications

items.abstract:
<jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title>
                  <jats:p>
                     <jats:named-content content-type="genus-species">Trichoderma reesei</jats:named-content>
                    can produce up to 100 g/liter of extracellular proteins. The major and industrially relevant products are cellobiohydrolase I (CBHI) and the hemicellulase XYNI. The genes encoding both enzymes are transcriptionally activated by the regulatory protein Xyr1. The first 850 nucleotides of the
                    <jats:italic>cbh1</jats:italic>
                    promoter contain 14 Xyr1-binding sites (XBS), and 8 XBS are present in the
                    <jats:italic>xyn1</jats:italic>
                    promoter. Some of these XBS are arranged in tandem and others as inverted repeats. One such
                    <jats:italic>cis</jats:italic>
                    element, an inverted repeat, plays a crucial role in the inducibility of the
                    <jats:italic>xyn1</jats:italic>
                    promoter. We investigated the impact of the properties of such
                    <jats:italic>cis</jats:italic>
                    elements by shuffling them by insertion, exchange, deletion, and rearrangement of
                    <jats:italic>cis</jats:italic>
                    elements in both the
                    <jats:italic>cbh1</jats:italic>
                    and
                    <jats:italic>xyn1</jats:italic>
                    promoter. A promoter-reporter assay using the
                    <jats:named-content content-type="genus-species">Aspergillus niger</jats:named-content>
                     <jats:italic>goxA</jats:italic>
                    gene allowed us to measure changes in the promoter strength and inducibility. Most strikingly, we found that an inverted repeat of XBS causes an important increase in
                    <jats:italic>cbh1</jats:italic>
                    promoter strength and allows induction by xylan or wheat straw. Furthermore, evidence is provided that the distances of
                    <jats:italic>cis</jats:italic>
                    elements to the transcription start site have important influence on promoter activity. Our results suggest that the arrangement and distances of
                    <jats:italic>cis</jats:italic>
                    elements have large impacts on the strength of the
                    <jats:italic>cbh1</jats:italic>
                    promoter, whereas the sheer number of XBS has only secondary importance. Ultimately, the biotechnologically important
                    <jats:italic>cbh1</jats:italic>
                    promoter can be improved by
                    <jats:italic>cis</jats:italic>
                    element rearrangement.
                  </jats:p>
                  <jats:p>
                     <jats:bold>IMPORTANCE</jats:bold>
                    In the present study, we demonstrate that the arrangement of
                    <jats:italic>cis</jats:italic>
                    elements has a major impact on promoter strength and inducibility. We discovered an influence on promoter activity by the distances of
                    <jats:italic>cis</jats:italic>
                    elements to the transcription start site. Furthermore, we found that the configuration of
                    <jats:italic>cis</jats:italic>
                    elements has a greater effect on promoter strength than does the sheer number of transactivator binding sites present in the promoter. Altogether, the arrangement of
                    <jats:italic>cis</jats:italic>
                    elements is an important factor that should not be overlooked when enhancement of gene expression is desired.
                  </jats:p>
title:
Influence of
                    cis
                    Element Arrangement on Promoter Strength in Trichoderma reesei

title: Characterization of erythrose reductases from filamentous fungi

items.abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>The saprophytic fungus<jats:named-content content-type="genus-species">Hypocrea jecorina</jats:named-content>(anamorph,<jats:named-content content-type="genus-species">Trichoderma reesei</jats:named-content>) is an important native producer of hydrolytic enzymes, including xylanases. Regarding principles of sustainability, cheap and renewable raw materials, such as<jats:sc>d</jats:sc>-xylose (the backbone monomer of xylan), have been receiving increasing attention from industries. Recently, it was demonstrated that small (0.5 to 1 mM) amounts of<jats:sc>d</jats:sc>-xylose induce the highest expression of xylanase in<jats:named-content content-type="genus-species">H. jecorina</jats:named-content>. However, it was also reported that active metabolism of<jats:sc>d</jats:sc>-xylose is necessary for induction. In this report, we demonstrate that xylitol, the next intermediate in the pentose pathway after<jats:sc>d</jats:sc>-xylose, does not trigger transcription of xylanase-encoding genes in<jats:named-content content-type="genus-species">H. jecorina</jats:named-content>QM9414. The highest level of transcription of xylanolytic enzyme-encoding genes occurred in an<jats:italic>xdh1</jats:italic>(encoding a xylitol dehydrogenase) deletion strain cultured in the presence of 0.5 mM<jats:sc>d</jats:sc>-xylose, suggesting that a metabolite upstream of xylitol is the inducer. The expression levels of xylanases in an<jats:italic>xdh1</jats:italic>-<jats:italic>lad1</jats:italic>double-deletion strain were lower than that of an<jats:italic>xdh1</jats:italic>deletion strain. This observation suggested that<jats:sc>l</jats:sc>-xylulose is not an inducer and led to the hypothesis that<jats:sc>l</jats:sc>-arabitol is the actual inducer of xylanase expression. A direct comparison of transcript levels following the incubation of the<jats:named-content content-type="genus-species">H. jecorina</jats:named-content>parental strain with various metabolites of the pentose pathway confirmed this hypothesis. In addition, we demonstrate that<jats:italic>xyr1</jats:italic>, the activator gene, is not induced in the presence of pentose sugars and polyols, regardless of the concentration used; instead, we observed low constitutive expression of<jats:italic>xyr1</jats:italic>.</jats:p>
title: L-Arabitol Is the Actual Inducer of Xylanase Expression in Hypocrea jecorina (Trichoderma reesei)
